meanings.definition: Pointing indirectly towards someone's guilt but not conclusively proving it.
meanings.sent1: The detective found some circumstantial evidence at the crime scene.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer argued that the case was built on circumstantial proof.
meanings.sent3: It was a circumstantial link to the suspect, but not enough to arrest him.
meanings.sent4: The circumstantial clues led the investigator to the real culprit.
meanings.sent5: The circumstantial details painted a clear picture of the crime.

meanings.definition: Involving or based on circumstances or dependent on circumstances.
meanings.sent1: Her decision was purely circumstantial and not based on logic.
meanings.sent2: The outcome of the experiment was circumstantial and unpredictable.
meanings.sent3: The circumstantial nature of the situation made it hard to predict.
meanings.sent4: Their success was circumstantial, relying on luck rather than skill.
meanings.sent5: The circumstantial factors influenced the final result significantly.
